[[Johnnie Wright]] | website = }} [[File:Kitty Wells Johnnie and Ruby Wright Jack Anglin Roy Acuff RKO Palace New York 1955.jpg|thumb|180px|Wright with [[Roy Acuff]], her parents, Kitty Wells and Johnnie Wright, and her uncle, Jack Anglin, as they played the [[Palace Theatre (Broadway)|RKO Palace]] in New York in 1955]] '''Ruby Wright''' (October 27, 1939 – September 27, 2009){{cite web |url=http://blogs.tennessean.com/tunein/2009/09/28/kitty-wells-daughter-ruby-wright-dies-at-age-69/ |title=Kitty Wells' daughter Ruby Wright dies at age 69 |accessdate=February 5, 2010 |format= |work=[[The Tennessean]]}} was an American [[country music]] singer-songwriter. Wright was the daughter of country singers [[Kitty Wells]] and [[Johnnie Wright]]. She sang with her parents as a young girl and at age 13, was signed by [[RCA Records]] as Ruby Wells because there was also a [[Ruby Wright (big band-era singer)|Ruby Wright]] who was a pop singer.{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/ruby-wright-mn0000357283|title=Ruby Wright|publisher=AllMusic|accessdate=January 8, 2013}} In the mid-1950s, she became part of an all-girl trio, 'Nita, Rita and Ruby.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vCEEAAAAMBAJ&dq=ruby+wells&pg=PA45|title=Country and Western Records|publisher=Billboard|date=November 26, 1955|accessdate=January 8, 2013}} The Nita of the trio was [[Anita Carter]] of the well-known [[Carter Family]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1473063/country-star-anita-carter-dies.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091107161638/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1473063/country-star-anita-carter-dies.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=November 7, 2009|title=Country Star Anita Carter Dies|date=July 30, 1999|publisher=CMT|accessdate=September 6, 2013}} Working with [[Chet Atkins]], the young singers enjoyed some success on record.{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/nita-rita-ruby-mn0001525082/songs|title=Nita, Rita and Ruby|publisher=AllMusic|accessdate=September 6, 2012}} Strictly a recording group, they did not make personal appearances or tours; Rita had a problem with stage fright which eventually meant the break-up of the trio. After the trio disbanded, Ruby began singing with her sister, Carol Sue, as The Wright Sisters. They were signed to a recording contract by [[Cadence Records]] also under the direction of Chet Atkins.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XBYEAAAAMBAJ&dq=wright+sisters&pg=PA36|title=Folk Talent & Tunes|author=Sachs, Bill|publisher=Billboard|date=March 10, 1962|accessdate=January 8, 2013}} Ruby also made some recordings as Ruby Wells with her father and uncle as [[Johnnie and Jack]] and Ruby.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yyAEAAAAMBAJ&dq=ruby+wells&pg=PA53|title=RCA Records ad|publisher=Billboard|page=53|date=January 14, 1956|accessdate=January 8, 2013}} Her most successful single was "Dern Ya", an [[answer song|answer]] to [[Roger Miller]]'s "[[Dang Me]]". She signed with [[Epic Records]] in 1966.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nEUEAAAAMBAJ&dq=ruby+wright+epic&pg=PA49|title=Nashville Scene|author=Whisenhunt, Elton|publisher=Billboard|date=April 23, 1966|accessdate=January 8, 2013}} Wright recorded for [[Plantation Records]] and Scorpion Records, as well as other small labels during the 1970s. Wright died of heart-related illness on September 27, 2009, at age 69.{{cite news|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/tennessean/obituary.aspx?page=lifestory&pid=133656073|title=Ruby Wright Taylor Obituary|date=September 29, 2009|publisher=The Tennessean|accessdate=January 8, 2013}} Her father, Johnnie, died two years later to the day.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.tennessean.com/tunein/2011/09/27/johnnie-wright-county-star-and-husband-of-kitty-wells-dies-at-97/|title=Johnnie Wright, country star and husband of Kitty Wells, dies at 97|last=Cooper|first=Peter|date=September 27, 2011|work=The Tennessean|accessdate=September 27, 2011}} ==Discography== ===Albums=== {| class="wikitable" !
